h i g h l i g h t s
Hybrid donor functionalized aluminasilica based nanomaterial was fabricated. Ligand field effect was effective for specific lanthanide ions separation. Nanomaterials was selective to Dy(III) or Lu(III) in presence of divers common ions.

Keywords: Ligand field effect Dysprosium(III) & Lutetium(III) Hybrid Lewis base EXAFS coordination Adsorption
a b s t r a c t
The separation of lanthanide (Ln(III)) elements from various waste materials is a significant issue facing developed countries. However, the chemical behaviour of Ln(III) are very similar and complex, and it is an important to understand clearly to optimize the separation processes under various conditions based on the ion-selective ligands and ligand field effect for specific Ln(III) separation with semi-cavity and high flexibility for competitiveness of industries and continuous economic growth. The study developed the hybrid Lewis base ligand functionalized alumina-silica based composite nanomaterials for heavier Ln (III) of Dy(III) and Ly(III) separation and recovery. The alumina-silica fabrication, intra-series separation, solution acidity, ion-selective and coordination mechanism by EXAFS were carried out systematically. The Dy(III) and Lu(III) adsorption was high in acidic region as the high pH area is avoided due to the hydroxyl precipitation. The adsorption data were fitted well with the Langmuir adsorption model for the both elements and the calculated maximum adsorption capacity was 125.44 and 129.77 mg/g for Dy(III) and Lu(III) ions, respectively. The ion selectivity was also performed in the presence of divers ions and Dy(III) or Lu(IIII) ions was preferentially adsorbed in a competitive environment. In the coordination mechanism by EXAFS, the Dy(III) and Lu(III) ions were strongly coordinated with the O and N atoms of the
hybrid Lewis base ligand in the composite nanomaterial. Moreover, adsorption–elution cyclic results demonstrated that Dy(III) and Lu(III) ions adsorbed composite nanomaterial could be effectively desorbed HNO3 acid, and the regenerated nanomaterial was able to repeated use without significant deterioration in its original performances. All these characteristics make the nanomaterial an ideal solid-phase materials for effective Dy(III) and Lu(III) ions adsorption in complicated matrix samples.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Rare earth metals have been widely used in all major applications in metallurgy, electronics, ceramics, optical, medical, magnets, chemical, and nuclear technologies due to their specific physical and chemical properties. For example, Dysprosium (Dy (III)) has used in magnetic alloys and ferrites for microwave purposes. In addition, Dy(III) has numerous applications in nuclear and metallurgical industries. Also the Dy(III) along with special steel is used to make nuclear reactor control rods. Moreover, in combination with vanadium and other rare earth, Dy(III) has been used in making laser materials [1,2]. Similarly, Lutetium (Lu(III)) is one of the heavy lanthanide (Ln(III)) elements with significant uses in the production of color televisions, energy-saving lamps and glasses [3]. However, the individual Ln(III) separation from each other is very difficult due to their similar chemical properties. On the other hand, the decrease in ionic radius with atomic number within the Ln(III) implied the predictable chemical differences from lanthanum through Lu(III) [4]. Therefore, there is room to separate the specific Ln(III) considering to the complexation ability at optimum condition. Then the fast, simple, and accurate Ln(III) separation with specific complexation mechanism is very important.
Several methods are used for separation of rare earth metals such as liquid extraction, sedimentation, oxidation, ion exchange and adsorption. Liquid extraction is the common method used for the separation and recovery of metal ions from aqueous solutions [5–8]. However, solid phase extraction/adsorption is replacing liquid extraction due to the absence of emulsion, great enrichment ratio, flexibility, short process, automated analytical techniques, safety and minimal costs [9,10]. Diverse adsorption materials such as organic chelate resin, silica and silica gel, alumina, titania, and molecular-imprinted polymers have been used as adsorbents for solid phase extraction [6,11–15]. In this connection, much of the research in selecting adsorbents in solid phase extraction/adsorption based on molecular embedded materials [16–18] is used for metal ions separation. From this stand point, nanomaterials can be used as suitable materials for this purpose due to their high surface area, specific pore size and pore volumes [1,19,20]. In this connection, diverse metal ions are separated with using different ligands group containing functionalized nanomaterials [21–25]. However, the Ln(III) has special interaction with Nand O-donor ligands based on the hard-soft acid-bases theory [26–28].
Recently, hybrid donor ligands are received much attention for specific Ln(III) separation due to their complexation ability and coordination mechanism [28,29]. In this study, N- and O- donor ligand containing N-methyl-N-phenyl-1,10-phenanthroline-2-car boxamide (MePhPTA) (Scheme 1) was used for Ln(III) intra-series separation after successful immobilization onto the aluminasilica composite nanomaterials. In the structure of MePhPTA, two N-atoms in phenanthroline and one O- atom in amide carbonyl are arranged for stable complex formation with the Ln(III). As the MePhPTA ligand is flexible, the most Ln(III) ions can be accommodated within this inner coordination sphere. The different radii of Ln(III) cause their different properties, such as charge densities
and hydration energy. Their hydration energy ranges from 3370 to 3760 kJ/mol from Ce(III) to Lu(III) ions [30,31]. Hence, the only way to design an ion-selective ligands and ligand field effect for specific Ln(III) separation with semi-cavity and high flexibility. Then the carrier inorganic materials have always bear the significant influence to open the functionality of the embedded organic ligand for knowing the ligand field effect [32–34]. In this connection, we have prepared alumina-silica composite nanomaterials and then incorporated with the MePhPTA ligand to understand the ligand effect while the ligand was same. Also this is the first time approach of the corresponding author to evaluate the Ln(III) separation based on the using of alumina-silica as carrier field. After Ln(III) intra-series observation by the functionalized composite nanomaterial, Dy(III) and Lu(III) ions are specific for effective separation at optimum condition. The incorporation of aluminum into the silica gives the materials with acidic active sites. It is also noted that the acidity of these solid materials generally arises from the cationic Bronsted acid sites from the coordination of aluminum species in the alumina-silica nanomaterials [35–37]. Then the acidity of composite nanomaterial surfaces is a key factor in Ln(III) separation and coordination. The present work describes our investigations of the adsorption of Dy(III) and Lu(III) ions on the composite nanomaterial.
The metal ions complexation on the solid surface functional group has been evident by the synchrotron based extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) methods [38–40]. The EXAFS analysis provides structural speciation with metal ions identification, coordination number and bond distance of the neighboring atoms around the metal atom [41]. The Ln(III) coordination mechanisms are evident of ligand doped silica based nanomaterials. However, specific interaction was evident with low bond distance of ytterbium probe atoms [28]. This gives an idea to investigate the Ln(III) surface interaction with N- and O-donor ligand based alumina-silica composite nanomaterials with specific focus on Dy (III) and Lu(III) complex formation during adsorption at optimum condition. Here, we present the results of Dy(III) and Lu(III) ions complex with MePhPTA ligand embedded composite nanomaterial based on the EXAFS method. Significant parameters such as incorporation ligand and alumina-silica, composite nanomaterial characterization, the Ln(III) transportation behaviour were determined systematically. It is also noted that diverse ligand embedded materials gave an advantages from the stand point of sensitivity, selectivity and coordination mechanism [42–44]. There is similar valance and ionic radii of the Ln(III) and trivalent actinides (Am(III), Cm(III), and Cf(III) [45–47], the Ln(III) separation method from the present study can be used to predict the behaviour of the actinide-series elements in the nuclear fuel processing in nuclear waste treatment.

sections.heading: 2.2. Preparation hybrid donor ligand of MePhPTA
sections.text: The hybrid donor of hard Lewis ligand of N-methyl-N-phenyl1,10-phenanthroline-2-carboxamide (MePhPTA) was prepared as reported elsewhere [29]. However, the preparation steps are indicated for reader understanding. At first, 1,10-phenanthroline-2carboxylic acid was refluxed in thionyl chloride for 24 h, and then residual thionyl chloride was removed. Then the product was dissolved in N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF), and added Nmethylaniline with stirred for 24 h. Then the desired product was purified by column chromatography.

sections.heading: 2.3. Preparation of mesoporous alumina-silica and composite nanomaterials
sections.text:
Mesoporous alumina-silica monolith was synthesized by using triblock copolymers as direct templating liquid-crystal phase using microemulsion system where F108 surfactant was used. Under typical synthesis conditions, the precursor solution (1.1 g of F108, 2,7 g of TMOS, and 0.45 g of Al(NO3)3 9H2O) was mixed and then shaken at 60 C until it became homogeneous [33]. The exothermic hydrolysis and condensation of TMOS occurred rapidly by addition of acidified aqueous 2.5 g of HCl (pH = 1.3) solution to this homogeneous solution. The flask that contained the synthesis composition was instantly connected to the rotary evaporator at 45 C to remove the methanol. After that the materials were dried at 45 C for 24 h to complete the drying process. Organic moieties were removed by calcination at 500 C under normal atmosphere for 6 h.
The composite nanomaterials were fabricated by direct immobilization method. The MePhPTA (55 mg) in DMF solution was contacted with 1.0 g alumina-silica and stirring the mixture solution for 6 h until MePhPTA saturation was achieved. The DMF was removed by a vacuum connected to a rotary evaporator at 80 C. The resulting materials were rinsed with water until no elution of MePhPTA was observed. The material was dried at 45 C for 6 h and ground to fine powder Ln(III) adsorption and coordination sample preparation. It is noteworthy that the MePhPTA was associated onto the alumina-silica by non-specific interaction via hydrogen bonding, Van der Waals forces and reversible covalent bonds.

sections.heading: 2.4. Sample preparation, Ln(III) coordination by EXAFS measurements and analyses
sections.text: The Ln(III) K-edge and LIII-edge of EXAFS were collected for Dy (III) and Lu(III). The solid samples of EXAFS measurement were prepared by dissolving of Dy(III) and Lu(III) in water solution (60 mM of Dy(NO3)3 and Lu(NO3)3 in aqueous solution). Then the composite nanomaterials were added and the mixture was shaken for 3 h. The solid composite nanomaterials were separated by filtration method. The Dy(III) and Lu(III) LIII-edge X-ray absorption measurements were performed at the Photon Factory, High Energy Accelerator Research Organization (KEK) on the beamline BL-27B under normal ring operating conditions using multi-element detector. The obtained EXAFS spectra were analyzed according to a standard method using the computer program code WinXAS ver.3.1 [48].

sections.heading: 2.5. The Ln(III) adsorption and desorption
sections.text:
The Ln(III) stock solutions were prepared by dissolving in aqueous solution. The stock solution was diluted as needed to investigate the several adsorption parameters. In the evaluation of intra-series separation behaviour, a desired concentration (2 mg/ L in each) of Ln(III) solution in 10 mL volume was taken in 15 mL test tube and 20 mg of composite nanomaterials was added. After that, the mixture was shaken for 2 h and the solid materials were separated by filtration method. The filtrate solution was checked by the ICP-AES. In the case of solution pH, Dy(III) and Lu(III) containing solution was adjusted using dilute nitric acid solution as needed.
After stirring for 1 h at room temperature, the solid materials were separated by filtration system and Dy(III) and Lu(III) concentrations in before and after adsorption operations were analyzed by ICP-AES. During the adsorption operation, the amount of adsorbed Dy(III)/Lu(III) was calculated according to the following equations:
Mass balance qe ¼ ðC0 CfÞ V=M ðmg=gÞ ð1Þ
and metal ion removal efficiency Re ¼ ðC0 CfÞ C0 100 ð%Þ ð2Þ
where V is the volume of the aqueous solution (L), and M is the weight of the composite nanomaterials (g), C0 and Cf are the initial and final concentrations of Dy(III)/Lu(III) ions in solutions, respectively.
To determine the kinetics performances, 10 mg of composite nanomaterials was added to 10 mL solution containing 10.0 mg/L concentrations of Dy(III)/Lu(III) ions. The mixture was then stirred, and samples were filtered at different time intervals. In case of maximum adsorption, 10 mg of composite nanomaterials was also added in different concentration of Dy(III)/Lu(III) ions and stirred for 3 h and filtrate solutions were analyzed by ICP-AES. The foreign ions effect was evaluated in single phase adsorption operation.
To evaluate the regeneration and reusability of the composite nanomaterial, elution experiments were conducted with pertinent
concentration nitric acid. First, 10 mL of 5 mM Dy(III)/Lu(III) ions was adsorbed by the 50 mg composite nanomaterials and then elution experiments were carried out using 0.30 M HNO3 acid. The adsorbed Dy(III)/Lu(III) ions containing composite nanomaterials was washed with deionized water and transferred into a 50 mL beaker. Then 5.0 mL of the eluting agent was added, and the mixture was stirred for 20 min. The concentration of Dy(III)/Lu(III) ions released from the composite nanomaterials into aqueous phase was analyzed by ICP-AES. The composite nanomaterials were reused in several cycles and clarify long-term use as costeffective materials. All experiments in this study were duplicated to assure the consistency and reproducibility of the results.

sections.heading: 2.6. Instruments and analyses
sections.text: Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) was obtained by using a JEOL (JEM-2100F) and operated at the accelerating voltage of the electron beam 200 kV. The TEM samples were prepared by dispersing the powder particles in ethanol solution using an ultrasonic bath and then dropped on copper grids. The N2 adsorptiondesorption isotherms were measured using the 3Flex analyzer (Micromeritics, USA) at 77 K. The pore size distribution was measured from the BJH adsorption. The alumina-silica and composite nanomaterial were pre-treated at 100 C for 3 h under vacuum until the pressure was equilibrated to 10 5 Torr before the N2 isothermal analysis. The specific surface area (SBET) was measured by using multi-point adsorption data from linear segment of the N2 adsorption isotherms using Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) theory. The Ln(III) concentrations were measured by ICP-AES (SII NanoTechnology Inc.). The ICP-AES instrument was calibrated using five standard solutions containing 0, 0.5, 1.0, 1.5 and 2.0 mg/L (for each element), and the correlation coefficient of the calibration curve was higher than 0.9999. In addition, sample solutions having complicated matrices were not used and no significant interference of matrices was observed.

sections.heading: 3.1. Characterization of alumina-silica and conjugate material
sections.text:
The N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms with specific area, pore size and pore volumes of the sample are shown in Fig. 1(A).
(A)
Fig. 1. N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of (a) inorganic alumina-silica and (b) liga structure (B and C).
The isotherms are IV type with H2 shaped hysteresis loops, indicating synthesized alumina-silica pores are mesoporous material [36,37]. The sharp capillary condensation steps were occurred at the relative pressure of 0.4–0.6, which is indicating the uniform mesoporous characteristic [33]. Also the alumina-silica has consisted of a high surface area of 379 m2/g with the pores size of 4.3 nm. The large pore size of alumina-silica is one of the advantages for the metal ions capturing when such materials were functionalized with organic ligand.
The morphologies of alumina-silica were also evaluated by the TEM. Fig. 1(B) shows the TEM images of the prepared aluminasilica composites. These images are clearly clarified that ordered channel like pore arrays are connected with porous structure. The STEM images also confirm the formation of mesoporous alumina-silica particles. The particle morphology and EDS mapping of the alumina-silica was characterized STEM-EDS mapping as shown in Fig. 2. In the STEM-EDS mapping, the alumina-silica mesostructures shows the presence of Si, Al, and O as the main element in this composite. The specific surface area, pore size and pore volume of MePhPTA immobilized composite nanomaterials was slightly decreased due to the incorporation of the organic ligand onto the alumina-silica. All these changes may be a consequence and the conjugate material exhibited appreciated porous structure for Ln(III) adsorption.

sections.heading: 3.2. Intra-series separation
sections.text:
The nanomaterials are exhibited significant interaction with the ligand based materials which can provide the specific Ln(III) separation only in the case of intra-series separation process [49]. However, the ligand field effect may have completely different interaction for the Ln(III). Moreover, the carrier material in this case is alumina-silica and significant interaction is expected. The intra-series separation tendency by the composite nanomaterials is shown in Fig. 3, where the initial fourteen Ln(III) ions concentration was 2.0 mg/L and the solution pH was 4.0. The data clarified that high sensitivity was possible only to the heavier Ln(III) of Dy (III) and Lu(III) based on the significant high adsorption as judged. It is also noted that intra-series separation behaviour is possible only by the ligand functionalized nanomaterials. Therefore, the Dy(III) and Lu(III) ions were selected in this study and others parameter were also determined.

sections.heading: 3.3. Effect of solution pH
sections.text:
The effects of solution acidity is associated with changes of the nanomaterial surface charge, Ln(III) ion speciation in solution and the competition effects of hydrogen ions with Ln(III) ions [1,50]. Moreover, the Ln(III) ions in aqueous solution is a complex phenomenon where Ln(III) may be present as ions as different compositions and different degrees of activity. Therefore, it is important to understand the nature of Ln(III) ions in solution for understanding their adsorption behaviour towards composite nanomaterials. Based on the pH acidity, the Ln(III) ionic species, namely Ln3+, Ln (OH)2+, Ln(OH)2+, Ln(OH)30 and Ln(OH)4 [2]. Fig. 4(A) shows the effect of solution acidity for the adsorption of Dy(III) and Lu(III) by the composite nanomaterial. The adsorption percentage was increased with increasing the pH from 1.0 to 4.0 and the decrease the adsorption efficiency. The maximum adsorption was exhibited at pH 4.0 in the case of both Dy(III) and Lu(III) ions. The higher pH is not counted because of the precipitation tendency over pH 5.0
[6,28]. In this pH area, the predominant species is Dy(III) and Lu (III). Therefore, pH 4.0 was selected for the subsequent adsorption operation in this study.

sections.heading: 3.4. Contact time
sections.text: The nanomaterials are exhibited high kinetic performances to comply the materials potentiality for large-scale use. The sufficient contact time is the matter of metal ions adsorption rate governing the residence time of the adsorption reaction of the proposed materials, which define the materials efficiency in terms of adsorption and sensitivity. Then a series of batch experiments was performed to define the optimum Dy(III) and Lu(III) ions adsorption, and the filtrate solution was checked by ICP–AES after each fraction. It is also noted that the initial concentrations of both ions were 10.0 mg/L in 20 mL volume, and the composite nanomaterial amount was 10 mg. The data are shown in Fig. 4(B). The results also clarified that Dy(III) and Lu(III) ions adsorption versus time curves was single, smooth and continuous indicating the monolayer adsorption onto the composite nanomaterial adsorbent surfaces [51]. In the beginning stage, the adsorption efficiency was sharply observed due to the high availability of the functional groups. On the other hand, increasing the contact time, adsorption efficiency was gradually increased and attained the equilibrium adsorption in 60 min and then tended to keep constant after that. Therefore, it was estimated that the contact time of 3 h was found to be sufficient to reach equilibriumwhen the initial both ions concentration was high to determine the maximum adsorption capacity. On the other hand, the granular resin and fibrous adsorbent are exhibited high adsorption rate for the divers anions removal from the wastewater samples [52–54].

sections.heading: 3.5. Adsorption isotherms
sections.text:
The adsorption isotherm parameter was evaluated to determine the relationship metal ions adsorbed on the functional material surface and the metal ions concentration remaining in the liquid phase. Then the maximum adsorption studies were conducted by varying the initial Dy(III) and Lu(III) ions concentration while the composite nanomaterial amount in each sample was kept identical. To evaluate the adsorption isotherms, the Langmuir model was used in this study to determine the maximum adsorption capacity. It is noted that the Langmuir equation cannot provide any mechanism for understanding of adsorption phenomena and it may be conveniently used to estimate the maximum capacity
at optimum conditions. The Langmuir adsorption isotherm is based on the assumption that all adsorption sites are energetically same and adsorption takes place at specific homogeneous sites with monolayer adsorption. Then the adsorption data for each Dy(III) and Lu(III) ions were fitted into the Langmuir isotherm according to Langmuir equation [55]:
Ce=qe ¼ 1=ðKLqmÞ þ Ce=qm ðlinear formÞ ð3Þ
where qe is the amount of adsorbed Dy(III) or Lu(III) (mg/g), Ce is the equilibrium concentration of the Dy(III) or Lu(III) in solution (mg/L), qm is the maximum adsorption capacity (mg/g) when the monolayer reached the saturation, and KL is the Langmuir equilibrium constant (L/mg) related to the free energy of adsorption. The adsorption isotherm (qe versus Ce) showed that the adsorption capacity, which is the mass (mg) of total Dy(III) or Lu(III) ions adsorbed per unit mass of the composite nanomaterial. The qm and KL were calculated from the intercept and slope of the linear plot, with Ce/qe versus Ce as shown in Fig. 5. The Langmuir adsorption constants calculated from the corresponding isotherms with the correlation coefficient values were R2 = 0.9923 for Dy(III) and R2 = 0.9941 for Lu(III) ions respectively. The calculated maximum adsorption capacities of the composite nanomaterial for Dy(III) and Lu(III) was 125.54 and 129.77 mg/L mg/g, respectively; and the adsorption coefficient KL, which is related to the apparent energy of adsorption, were calculated to be 1.62 and 1.78 L/mg, respectively. Isotherm shape was a typical L-shaped adsorption isotherm, indicating progressive saturation of the solid as evident of
the composite nanomaterial as evident in Fig. 5. In contrast, the ratio between metal ions concentration remaining in the solution and that adsorbed on the solid materials decreased with increasing metals ions concentration generating a concave curve [56]. However, the present data clarified the progressive saturation of the solid nanomaterial. In addition, the correlation coefficient indicates that the adsorption process was fitted well by the Langmuir isotherms model and the adsorption process can be described by the formation of monolayer coverage of the adsorbate on the composite nanomaterial surface.

sections.heading: 3.6. EXAFS measurement coordination mechanism
sections.text:
The coordination of Dy(III) and Lu(III) ions onto composite nanomaterial were successfully measured by EXAFS spectra. The Fourier transforms of EXAFS data are shown in Fig. 6 where phase shift was not corrected. Fig. 6 shows consist of 2 specific shells where the first shell was very sharp and corresponding to 2.0 Å. This shell is referred to the O and N atoms of the ligand of MePhPTA with Dy(III) and Lu(III) ions at specific bond distances [36]. The second shell was shorter compared with the first shell and corresponding to bonding of C atoms. It is also indicated that no report has published to have the EXAFS measurement on Dy (III) or Lu(III) adsorbed onto the alumina-silica functionalized with hybrid Lewis base ligand based solid nanomaterials. These results clarified that the Dy(III) and Lu(III) ions have strong coordination
otherms and (B) linear form of Langmuir plot of the composite nanomaterials for Dy
complexation affinity to make suitable complexes with O and N donor containing hybrid Lewis base ligand.

sections.heading: 3.7. Ion selective effect
sections.text: The effects of common ions such as Na+, K+, Ca2+, Mg2+ and Zn2+ on the adsorption of Dy(III) and Lu(III) ions were investigated to understand the selectivity of the proposed composite nanomaterial. It is noted that the added diverse ions concentration was 10 mg/L while the Dy(III) and Lu(III) ions concentration was 2.0 mg/L. The results are shown in Fig. 7(A). The data also clarified that these foreign ions had no significant interferences on the adsorption of Dy(III) or Lu(III) ions at optimum conditions, which complies the high selectivity to the Dy(III) and Lu(III) ions. Therefore, the composite nanomaterial is suitable for the selective recovery from complicated matrix. The high selectivity is strongly depended on several factors. One is the ligand functionality of MePhPTA which is conjugated by the alumina-silica for the high affinity to the Ln(III). The second is the ion size selectivity which is fitted the cavity of the composite nanomaterial [6,57,58]. The third is the coordination mechanism due to the alumina-silica functionalized with MePhPTA for suitable stable complexation coordination of Dy(III) and Lu(III) ions. This is postulated that the coordination mechanism may dominate in the selectivity parameter as defined by the preceding section.

sections.heading: 3.8. Elution and reuses
sections.text: The elution and reuses are carried out on the ratio to the mass eluted from the composite nanomaterial to the mass adsorbed onto the composite nanomaterials. The elution study was investigated by HNO3 acid treatment as considering from the pH study. It was found that 0.30 M HNO3 solution was the efficient eluent with the elution efficiency reaching 99% both for Dy(III) and Lu (III) ions. The composite nanomaterial was saturated with Dy(III) or Lu(III) ions and then eluted with 0.30 M HNO3 to release the adsorbed Dy(III) or Lu(III) ions in order to regenerate the nanomaterial without damaging the cage cavities. After elution, the composite nanomaterial was simultaneously regenerated into the initial form for the next operation after rinsing with water. The reusability of composite nanomaterial was carried out by repeating the adsorption-elution-regeneration process for six cycles as depicted in Fig. 7(B). However, the adsorption efficiency for both ions was slightly decreased after six cycles compared with 1st cycle data, indicating good elution properties of the nanomaterial and high reuses of the adsorption process. Therefore, the composite nanomaterial can be used repeatedly for the selective adsorption of Dy(III) and Lu(III) ions from solution at optimum condition.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text:
In this work, extensive laboratory experiments were performed for selective Dy(III) and Lu(III) ions adsorption and recovery based on ligand field effect and coordination mechanism by EXAFS using hybrid Lewis base anchored alumina-silica based composite nanomaterial. The nanomaterial clarified an excellent adsorption properties in terms of sensitivity and selectivity because of the coordination complexation with O and N donor atoms on its surface which can create intensive interaction with Dy(III) or Lu(III) ions as defined by the EXAFS spectra data analysis. The carrier material of alumina-silica played a significant role for the heavier lanthanide as judged from the intra-series separation behaviour. The Dy(III) and Lu(III) adsorption efficiency was depended on the initial concentration, solution acidity and equilibration contact time. Moreover, the adsorption data were fitted well with the Langmuir adsorption isotherms model and confirmed the monolayer coverage onto the composite nanomaterial. The maximum adsorption capacity of Dy(III) and Lu(III) was 125.54 and 129.77 mg/g, respectively. The foreign ions did not adversely affect the Dy(III) and Lu(III) ion adsorption by the composite nanomaterial. The adsorbed Dy(III) and Lu(III) ions were successfully eluted

with 0.30 M HNO3 and subsequently regenerated into the initial form for next operation without damaging of cage cavities and structure. In can be concluded that many possibilities open up for scientists involved in complex design for lanthanide separation based on the ligand field effect, which the authors now makes feasible.

The authors extend their appreciation to the International Scientific Partnership Program ISPP at King Saud University for funding this research work through ISPP# 87. The EXAFS experiments have been carried out with the approvals of KEK, Tsukuba (Proposal No. 2014G102). The author also wishes to thanks to the anonymous reviewers and editor for their helpful suggestions and enlightening comments.
